page.name: Key Concepts for Writing to Improve Reading
page.content:
Learn how to:

  1. Ask questions 
  2. Make inferences
  3. Predict
  4. Visualize
  5. Summarize
Ask questions 
A supporting practice for students to increase their reading comprehension is by generating questions about the information they encounter in the text. The goal in this strategy is to help students stop and think about what they read, assuring understanding and remembering important details. By generating questions before, during, and after reading a passage, students can build comprehension skills by:
  • Making predictions about what they will read based on the title, first sentence or paragraph, images, etc.
  • Identifying important facts or concepts
  • Making a mental note or actual notes about what they are reading
  • Anticipating the ways in which they might be asked to demonstrate or apply their learning. What would I say, write, or show about the passage I read?
Make inferences
Making inferences means choosing a probable or likely explanation from the facts in the text. Many students grasp how to make inferences through teacher modeling. Think aloud as you make inferences about something you read, a video you watched, etc. Model or demonstrate making an inference by:
  • Reading some text
  • Pausing to make a note that includes the text clues the author gives 
  • Stating and/or writing the inferences you would make  
There are, most often, several ways to draw conclusions from what an author may be implying. Illustrate that in your demonstrations. 
Predict

Predicting encourages readers to actively think ahead and ask questions. It supports readers to understand, make connections to what they are reading, interact with the text, and improve reading comprehension.​

Educators can help readers learn to predict in the following ways: ​

  • Before reading: Read the title and make a prediction about what the passage will be about​

  • During reading: Stop and compare what readers predicted to what is actually happening in the text​

  • Following reading: Reflect with readers on their predictions. This will build readers' observational and critical thinking skills and improving comprehension.

Remember, making predictions is not done to be “right” or “wrong," but rather to focus on change and how what they read modified the prediction. 
Visualize

Visualization enhances attention because it keeps the reader focused on the subject. In fact, visualization while reading has been shown to increase comprehension dramatically because it requires readers to weave together background knowledge, text evidence, and create an image that matches the story or information they are reading.  

Educators can help readers learn to visualize by: 

  • Periodically reminding them to make mental images 
  • Asking them to stop reading periodically and check to make sure what they see in their mind matches the description in the text
  • Periodically stopping and drawing images from the text 
  • Reading a poem or short description aloud and having the learners draw and then compare images of what they heard 

Summarize

Summarizing helps build working memory. By periodically stopping and recalling the key ideas or main points of a passage, learners can increase their comprehension and engagement. 

Help learners summarize by:

  • Asking them to underline the most important sentence in each paragraph
  • Randomly asking them to stop reading and share with their neighbor the key idea in the section they just read
  • Having them write a movie trailer for the passage
  • Having them re-write the title for the piece they just finished and explain why they changed the title 
  • Having them recap the story in 50, 25, and then 10 words or less
